text: hi uh my name is marit f I'm from the Netherlands uh and I'm here today to talk to you about reading
code um the reason for this talk is that we actually spend more time reading code
then we do writing code we spend time reading code when we
are adding or changing functionality when we are fixing bugs or even trying to find where the bug is uh when we're
trying to understand a new code base when we're doing code reviews when we're
learning new things Etc in fact research has shown that
developers on average spend as much time as 58% of their time trying to
comprehend existing source code uh this is a quote from the book The programmer's Brain by Felina hermans
Felina hermans is a professor of Computer Science Education in the Netherlands at the F University and she
wrote a book uh called the programmer's brain uh which is what what every programmer needs to know about cognition
so she really goes into how we learn programming Etc uh and also how we read
code so even though we spend more time reading cone code than writing code we
don't practice reading code much and uh during one of fela's talks called
how to teach programming and other things she talked about uh research from
the early 1990s where they had a group of students who had to learn programming Concepts
and they split the group of students into three groups uh one group would write code and
read code one group would write code and read code with an explanation of choices
that were made when writing the code and the third group would only read code
with explanations of the choices that were made and what they found was that the second and third group actually did
better at understanding the programming Concepts than the first group however we
learn programming mostly by writing code uh so her talk prompted the
question from someone so what if we practice reading code explicitly
and that's how code reading club was born uh Felina along with some other people started a code Reading Club where
they would do structured exercises with printed code on a piece
of paper and then annotating that code using structured exercises to try and
make sense of the code and when I heard about that I was very enthusiastic I was
like oh I really want to try that so I got very lucky uh because a friend of mine said hey we're starting starting a
code Reading Club do you want to join I'm like yes I do so uh I'm currently part of uh a monthly code reading club
with several people who live in different countries Germany Netherlands UK the US even who have different roles
developers testers coaches work with different programming languages Java and
cotlin net someone brought psql at some point um and I really really love doing
this Cod reading club because we learn structured exercises so ways of
approaching how to read code but also because we have people in the group with
different experience different background different knowledge we get a lot of different insights and I'm
actually I I almost love that more than practicing the code reading um because
it's so interesting to see what other people's people notice about a piece of code as well as making more explicit
what your own assumptions are about the piece of code that you're reading uh by talking about it so um I started giving
code reading workshops as well at at some conferences and and meetups and obviously because I work for
a company that creates idees one of the questions that I would uh get was okay but what about the IDE normally I read
code in an IDE this is true the structure exercises are taking the skill
of code reading a little bit out of context by printing it on a piece of paper and practicing it there um so
that's kind of how the idea for this talk was born I want to combine the two and look at okay what are some of the
structured exercises that we can do but also what are some of the features of
our IDE that we can use for different situations where we need to read code so I want to look at different
strategies that we can use for for different tasks uh and how we can approach getting better at at reading
code and and familiarizing oursel with a codebase or a piece of code I want to focus on reading code to
understand the code rather than uh judging the code so I'm not going to look at code reviews too much I'm going
to start with reading code to understand the code and and get a mental picture of
what's going on so I want to look at first how to get
the bigger picture how to familiarize yourself with a new code base and the context for that code base so um diving
into the details searching and navigating and finally when you find a piece of code that you really need to
understand some of the hints that your IDE can give you and some structured exercises that you can
do um so to get the bigger picture when you're on boarding to a new team or a new codebase it might be because you
switch teams at work work or you joined a new company or you might want to contribute to an open source project and
and need to figure out how that works or where to find the thing that you want to fix or add so you need to figure out what does
the code do um relevant to that is also the
context of the code there's things that you can find in the code base but also a lot of things that cannot be
codified um and hopefully if you're joining a new team someone on the team team will take the time to give you a
bit of an overview of this is what this code base is for this is the place in
the landscape this is these are the other applications that are using this
our system or these are the the business departments that are that we are working with um possibly also a bit of a road
map this is what we're working on this is where we are going are we actively adding features at the moment Are we
more in a maintenance phase all of these things are relevant if you're going to be working on the code base but you
might not necessarily be able to find them in the code code itself you might need background
knowledge both in terms of business knowledge uh especially if you're switching Industries or moving to a team
on a completely different side of the of the organization but you might also need
knowledge in the programming domain particular architectural patterns design patterns you might need to read some
documentation to give you a better picture of what the codebase does um maybe the documentation will also
explain some of the concepts both on the business side and the um technical side
you might want to read the documentation for some of the new technologies that you'll be working with uh do some
research while you're trying to get an idea of of the bigger picture I find it extremely helpful to take notes I
definitely love drawing little diagrams of my current state of understanding or
misunderstanding of the code I like to write down my questions sometimes I'll find the answers as I'm exploring
sometimes I'll need to either look for the answer by Googling or ask someone if I can't figure it out or want some help
on the context um but by taking notes uh and writing down your questions you also
sort of have a checklist of the things that you want to know to further explore rather than just going down all
the rabbit holes of finding out more uh relevant information and not really
having a clear idea of whether you know uh whether you've researched the concepts you wanted to so like I said
draw diagrams write down questions maybe if you have suggestions of I would do
this differently because you know we all have our personal preferences of how we want to write the code um and even
though we said we wouldn't pass judgment if there are things that are bugging you maybe write them down put the list to
the side and once you've further explored the codebase and have a better picture of what's going on on see if you
still want to change those things and maybe then you can discuss them with the team
um so the strategies for getting a bigger picture would be to First identify the components that make up the
code so that can be modules or packages or even classes on a smaller scale
identify relationships and dependencies between those and identify any concepts
that you're unfamiliar with and might want to research further uh the reason to do this is a bit of
science on how our brain works um our working memory can hold a limited number
of chunks and we used to think that it was seven plus or minus two and it turns
out that it is actually probably less than that so more like two to six things that we can hold in our working memory
at a time so if we familiarize ourself ourselves with architectural patterns
design patterns uh and concept we can store each of those as one chunk
rather than the individual components that make up a pattern and quickly fill out all the slots so having a bit of
familiarity will make it easier for our working memory to work with the
code so the first thing to do when onboarding to a new code base will be to
check out the code and see if you can build it uh the last team I was on before I joined jet brains this was

functional style for example using refactorings if you're more used to reading a a functional style and that
will make it more familiar to you and help you understand it um maybe don't
commit those changes but it's okay to play with it to make it easier for you to

Behavior Uh which is something that I do recommend because um I once worked on a code base

doesn't necessarily tell you what's going on and you need more time to figure out what went wrong um so give
